Line 12: Line 12:  
Richard Paul and Linda Elder of the Foundation for Critical Thinking define ethics as "a set of concepts and principles that guide us in determining what behavior helps or harms sentient creatures".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The ''[[Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' states that the word ethics is "commonly used interchangeably with '[[morality]]' ... and sometimes it is used more narrowly to mean the moral principles of a particular tradition, group or individual."<ref>John Deigh in Robert Audi (ed), ''The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1995.</ref> Paul and Elder state that, "most people confuse ethics with behaving in accordance with social conventions, religious beliefs and the law", and don't treat ethics as a stand-alone concept.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |title= The Miniature Guide to Understanding the Foundations of Ethical Reasoning|edition= |last1= Paul|first1= Richard|last2= Elder|first2= Linda|year= 2006|publisher= Foundation for Critical Thinking Free Press|location= United States|isbn= 0-944583-17-2|page= np}}</ref>
 
Richard Paul and Linda Elder of the Foundation for Critical Thinking define ethics as "a set of concepts and principles that guide us in determining what behavior helps or harms sentient creatures".<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The ''[[Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' states that the word ethics is "commonly used interchangeably with '[[morality]]' ... and sometimes it is used more narrowly to mean the moral principles of a particular tradition, group or individual."<ref>John Deigh in Robert Audi (ed), ''The Cambridge Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1995.</ref> Paul and Elder state that, "most people confuse ethics with behaving in accordance with social conventions, religious beliefs and the law", and don't treat ethics as a stand-alone concept.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |title= The Miniature Guide to Understanding the Foundations of Ethical Reasoning|edition= |last1= Paul|first1= Richard|last2= Elder|first2= Linda|year= 2006|publisher= Foundation for Critical Thinking Free Press|location= United States|isbn= 0-944583-17-2|page= np}}</ref>
    −
The word ethics in English can mean several things. It can refer to philosophical ethics—a project that attempts to use reason in order to answer various kinds of ethical questions.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} It can also be used to describe a particular person's own, idiosyncratic principles or habits. For example: "Joe has good ethics." It may also be used to characterize the questions of right-conduct in some specific sphere, even when such right-conduct is not examined philosophically: "business ethics," or "the ethics of child-rearing" may refer, but need not refer, to a philosophical examination of such issues.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Philosophical ethics, or "ethical theory," is not the exclusive use of the term "ethics" in English.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
+

For example: "Joe has good ethics."{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} It may also be used to characterize the questions of right-conduct in some specific sphere, even when such right-conduct is not examined philosophically: "business ethics," or "the ethics of child-rearing" may refer, but need not refer, to a philosophical examination of such issues.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} Philosophical ethics, or "ethical theory," is not the exclusive use of the term "ethics" in English.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
